newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - July 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - July 3.

text.p: The following is a summary of major stories in leading South Korean newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy.

- The Council for Political Development the mainstream faction of the ruling New Korea Party, declared that it will not rally its support to any particular candidate in the presidential nomination race of the party.
- Asia Motors on Wednesday said its union members have agreed to reduce the number of employees by 1,447.
- North Korean defector Hwang Jang-yop will hold a news conference at the headquarters of the Agency for National Security Planning in Seoul around July 10.

- Construction on the two 1,000 megawatt nuclear reactors to be built in Sinpo, North Korea, is likely to begin next month as the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) on Wednesday finalised wage levels for workers, communications and medical services with North Korea.

- The nation's imports of consumer goods in the first five months of the year rose by 1.5 percent, compared to the same period a year ago. It was the lowest growth rate since 1993, according the the Bank of Korea.
- Songsu Bridg will be reopened at noon on Thursday after two and half year of repairs. A section of the bridge collapsed in October 1994 during morning rush hour, killing 32 commuters.
